sn42.12:4.1: Then Rāsiya the chief went up to the Buddha,
sn42.12:4.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn42.12:4.4: “Sir, I have heard this: ‘The ascetic Gotama criticizes all forms of mortification. He categorically condemns and denounces those who practice mortification and rough living.’
sn42.12:4.6: repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? Is their explanation in line with the teaching? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism?”
sn42.12:4.8: do not repeat what I have said. They misrepresent me with what is false, baseless, and untrue.
sn42.12:5.1: These two extremes should not be cultivated by one who has gone forth.

sn42.12:5.7: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn42.12:19.1: These three practitioners of mortification and rough living are found in the world.

sn42.12:25.1: There are these three kinds of wearing away that are realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know them for themselves.
sn42.12:25.3: A greedy person, because of greed, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both.
sn42.12:25.4: When they’ve given up greed they don’t have such intentions.
